messageBody:
I understand your reasoning, but from a personal point of view, I'd prefer
to see the one physical test fail during one of the logical tests. I see
the logical tests as just a series of asserts within the same testcase, but
refactored to remove 'some' duplication.

eg.

public void testRangeValues() {
assertEquals(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
assertEquals(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
assertEquals(new Integer(0), new Integer(0));
}

becomes...

public void testRangeValues() {
testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
testTwoIntegers(new Integer(0), new Integer(0));
}


Note: This is a simplistic example...obviously we'd be doing more than
testing two integers - to answer the original question.





> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: 23 July 2003 17:29
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to run same testcase with 20 different
> arg-values to test diff. results
>
>
> >So said malvoisin on 2003-07-23 --------------------
> >but but but...
> >
> >public void testMax() {
> > testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
> >}
> >
> >public void testMin() {
> > testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
> >}
> >
> >..
> >..
> >..
>
> This is unnecessary duplication.
>
> >would still work, and is more concise than creating 200 new test
> >classes with different setUp/tearDown methods.
>
> You certainly don't need THAT.
>
> >what's so hated about
> >grouping them all in the same method, though?
>
> If I run three tests, I want JUnit to report 3 runs, not 1. It
> will eventually confuse someone at a key moment. It always does.
> It's like trying to remember a lie: eventually it catches up with
> you -- it's easier to tell the truth from the beginning.
>
> >sure you're running
> >multiple tests in one test method, but it is still easy to track
> >specific problems down since you get the stack trace.
>
> True enough, but it doesn't give me an accurate picture of the
> number of tests in the system.
>
> Simple solution:
>
> public void testTwoIntegers() {
> // use a and b from fixture
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> int[][] testData = new int[][] {
> {Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue},
> {Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue},
> ...
> };
>
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> for (int i = 0; i < testData.length; i++) {
> suite.addTest(new IntegerTest(testData[i][0], testData[i][1]);
> }
>
> return suite;
> }
>
> public IntegerTest(int a, int b) {
> super("testTwoIntegers"); // leverage TestCase reflection
> to run test method 'testTwoIntegers'
> // set fixture for test
> this.a = a;
> this.b = b;
> }
>
> An alternative, with less magic, is to override runTest().
>
> public void testTwoIntegers(int a, int b) {
> // test implementation
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> int[][] testData = new int[][] {
> {Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue},
> {Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue},
> ...
> };
>
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> for (int i = 0; i < testData.length; i++) {
> suite.addTest(new IntegerTest() {
> protected void runTest() {
> testTwoIntegers(testData[i][0], testData[i][1]);
> }
> });
> }
>
> return suite;
> }
>
> I prefer the first because it avoids a bunch of anonymous subclasses.
>
